(Sec. 323) Requires the senior acquisition executive of the Air Force instead of the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics to determine if the Air Force has obtained sufficient data to establish that it is paying a fair and reasonable price for F117 engine sustainment, maintenance, repair, or overhaul.

(Sec. 324) Requires each of the service acquisition executives of the military departments to: (1) initiate a pilot program in FY2016 for product improvement under the authority provided in the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008, and (2) spend at least $5 million in working capital funds in FY2016 to support the initiative.

(Sec. 325) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report on equipment purchased from foreign entities that could be manufactured in U.S. arsenals or depots.

Subtitle D--Other Matters

(Sec. 333) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a plan for the improved management and oversight of the systems, processes, and controls involved in the disposal of excess DOD property by the Defense Logistics Agency Disposition Services.

(Sec. 334) Encourages DOD to enter into contracts with third-party vendors to provide free access to wireless high-speed Internet and network connections for certain members of the Armed Forces deployed overseas.

(Sec. 335) Permits certain contracts or subcontracts entered into under the Armament Retooling and Manufacturing Support (ARMS) Initiative to include an option to extend the term for an additional 25 years.

(Sec. 336) Prohibits any DOD function performed by civilian employees that is tied to a certain base from being converted to contractor performance until DOD assesses whether sufficient outreach has been carried out to assist small businesses in the area of the base that are owned and controlled by women and socially and economically disadvantaged individuals.

TITLE IV--MILITARY PERSONNEL AUTHORIZATIONS

Subtitle A--Active Forces

(Sec. 401) Authorizes specified end strengths for Active Duty personnel of the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 402) Establishes new minimum Active Duty end strengths for the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force.

Subtitle B--Reserve Forces

(Sec. 411) Authorizes specified end strengths for Selected Reserve personnel.

(Sec. 412) Authorizes specified end strengths for Reserves on Active Duty in support of the Reserves.

(Sec. 413) Authorizes specified end strengths for military technicians (dual status).

(Sec. 414) Establishes the maximum end strengths for the Reserve Components of the Army and Air Force for non-dual status technicians.

(Sec. 415) Authorizes the maximum number of Reserve Component personnel who may be on Active Duty or full-time National Guard duty during FY2016 to provide operational support.

Subtitle C--Authorization of Appropriations

(Sec. 421) Authorizes appropriations for Military Personnel at the levels identified in section 4401 of this bill.

(Sec. 422) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report containing specified assessments, evaluations, and details regarding the force structure of the Army.

TITLE V--MILITARY PERSONNEL POLICY

Subtitle A--Officer Personnel Policy

(Sec. 501) Specifies that if the Secretary of a military department determines that one or more officers were not placed on an all-fully-qualified-list for promotion because of administrative error, the Secretary may prepare a supplemental list for promotion containing the names of the officers.

(Sec. 502) Permits the Secretaries of the military departments to defer, until age 68, the mandatory retirement age of a general or flag officer serving as Chief or Deputy Chief of Chaplains of the Army, Navy, or Air Force.

(Sec. 503) Implements GAO recommendations on the definition and availability of general and flag officer costs and requires DOD to submit a report to Congress describing the costs.

Subtitle B--Reserve Component Management

(Sec. 511) Provides that the purpose of a Reserve Component special selection board is limited to the correction of errors at a mandatory promotion board.

(Sec. 512) Includes members who occupy key federal positions in the individuals who must be screened for continued service in the Ready Reserve.

(Sec. 513) Exempts military technicians (dual-status) from civilian employee furloughs.

(Sec. 514) Requires the Chief of the National Guard Bureau to submit to Congress and other specified officials an annual report on the personnel, training, and equipment requirements for the non-federalized National Guard to support civilian authorities in preventing and responding to non-catastrophic domestic disasters.

(Sec. 515) Authorizes the use of the National Guard to support firefighting operations, missions, or activities, including aerial firefighting employment of the Modular Airborne Firefighting System, undertaken in support of a civilian authority or a state or federal agency.

(Sec. 516) Requires DOD to establish an electronic system for members of the Ready Reserve of the Armed Forces to track their operational active-duty service performed.

Subtitle C--Consolidation of Authorities to Order Members of Reserve Components to Perform Duty

(Sec. 521) Consolidates the number of Reserve Component status category authorities under which Reserve Component members may be called to duty from 30 to 6 and directs the Secretaries concerned to develop policies and procedures to carry out the changes.

(Sec. 522) Amends Reserve duty authorities to redesignate inactive duty to encompass operational and other duties performed while in an active duty status.

(Sec. 523) Provides authorizations and limitations for the mobilization and the call-up to Active Duty or Inactive duty of the Ready Reserve, Selected Reserve, and certain members of the Individual Ready Reserve. Specifies purposes and limitations of the duty. Authorizes the Secretary of Defense to organize and administer the Reserve Components and specifies authorities and limitations.

(Sec. 524) Authorizes the required training, field exercises, and other duty performed by the National Guard. Sets forth the purposes, restrictions, and limitations for a call to order of the National Guard.

(Sec. 525) Authorizes clerical and conforming amendments to the titles of the U.S. Code related to amendments made by this subtitle.

(Sec. 526) Establishes October 1, 2017, as the implementation date for this subtitle and requires the Secretaries concerned to submit an implementation plan to Congress.

Subtitle D--General Service Authorities

(Sec. 531) Provides authority through 2020 for the Secretary of a military department to develop and provide incentives to encourage individuals to accept an appointment as a commissioned officer, accept an appointment as a warrant officer, or enlist in the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 532) Amends the Duncan Hunter National Defense Authorization Act of Fiscal Year 2009 to expand the authority to conduct pilot programs on career flexibility to enhance retention of members of the Armed Forces. Removes limitations on the number of participants in the program. (Under the program, officers and enlisted members of the Armed Forces may be inactivated from active duty in order to meet personal or professional needs and returned to active duty at the end of the period of inactivation.)

(Sec. 533) Modifies the waiting period and congressional notification requirements for changes in the ground combat exclusion policy for female members of the Armed Forces. Requires DOD to notify Congress at least 30 days before a change is implemented.

(Sec. 534) Requires gender-neutral occupational standards developed by the Secretaries of the military departments to measure the combat readiness of combat units, including special operations forces.

(Sec. 535) Specifies the burden of proof for investigations conducted by an Inspector General, reviews performed by a board of correction of military records, and reviews conducted by the Secretary of Defense related to protected communications of members of the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 536) Permits veterans to change their name on a certificate of discharge or an order of acceptance of resignation in order to reflect a change in gender identity and a different name.

(Sec. 537) Requires the Army to develop a breastfeeding policy for female members of the Army.

(Sec. 538) Expresses the sense of Congress that the United States should (1) continue to recognize and promote diversity in the Armed Forces; and (2) honor those from diverse backgrounds and religious traditions who have made sacrifices in serving the United States through the Armed Services.

(Sec. 539) Requires DOD to establish a process by which the commander of a military installation in the United States may authorize a member of the Armed Forces assigned to duty at the installation to carry a concealed personal firearm on the installation if it is necessary as a personal- or force-protection measure.

Subtitle E--Military Justice, Including Sexual Assault and Domestic Violence Prevention and Response

(Sec. 541) Requires DOD to develop a policy to standardize the training for Special Victims' Counsel, establish performance measures and standards, require a Special Victims' Counsel to have adequate criminal justice experience, and ensure that Special Victims' Counsel are assigned to locations that maximize face-to-face interactions with clients.

(Sec. 542) Authorizes DOD to provide Special Victims' Counsel services to a civilian DOD employee who is the victim of an alleged sex-related offense.

(Sec. 543) Includes former dependents of a service member or former service members among those eligible for access to a Special Victims' Counsel.

(Sec. 544) Permits victims of alleged sex-related offenses to receive representation and assistance from a Special Victims' Counsel in any retaliatory proceedings related to the victim's report of the offense.

(Sec. 545) Requires a victim of a sex-related offense to be notified of the availability of a Special Victims' Counsel prior to interviewing or requesting a statement from the victim.

(Sec. 546) Amends the Uniform Code of Military Justice (UCMJ) to permit victims to participate in punitive proceedings by submitting written material for consideration by a commanding officer prior to imposing punishment, mitigating punishment, or considering an appeal under non-judicial punishment proceedings. Permits the victim to submit written material for consideration during a separation proceeding and requires the separation authority to consider the impact on the victim prior to making a decision.

(Sec. 547) Requires the report of the results of a preliminary hearing under Article 32 of the UCMJ to be provided to the victim at the same time the report is delivered to the accused.

(Sec. 548) Modifies the mandatory minimum sentence for certain sex-related offenses to require confinement for at least two years.

(Sec. 549) Requires DOD to establish a strategy to prevent retaliation against members of the Armed Forces who report or intervene on behalf of sexual assault victims.

(Sec. 550) Requires DOD to develop a plan to improve prevention and response to sexual assaults of male members of the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 551) Requires the Secretary of a military department to ensure that commanders of Junior and Senior Reserve Officers' Training Corps units and other individuals of the Reserve Officers' Training Corps receive: (1) regular sexual assault prevention and response training, and (2) information regarding legal assistance and the sexual assault prevention and response program.

(Sec. 552) Modifies Rule 1103 of the Manual for Courts-Martial (preparation of record of trial) to require a complete record of trial in any general or special court-martial proceeding.

(Sec. 553) Requires DOD to include additional data in its annual sexual assault prevention and response report, including reports of cases under the Family Advocacy Program, data related to sexual harassment, and additional retaliation data.

(Sec. 554) Requires DOD to retain all elements of the case file in investigations of sex-related offenses for at least 50 years.

(Sec. 555) Prohibits DOD treatment facilities from releasing mental health records of alleged victims of sex-related offenses without an order from a military judge or Article 32 officer.

(Sec. 556) Requires DOD to make records of court-martial proceedings available through a public website.

(Sec. 557) Requires DOD to create a database to track sex offenders.

(Sec. 558) Requires DOD to examine the process for implementing changes to the UCMJ to develop options for streamlining the process and ensure that legal guidance is published when the changes are implemented.

Subtitle F--Member Education, Training, and Transition

(Sec. 561) Excludes any day on which a member: (1) performed full-time training or annual training duty, and (2) attended a school designated as a service school from the calculation of continuous days of Active Duty for the purpose of receiving preseparation counseling.

(Sec. 562) Requires DOD and the Department of Homeland Security to permit a member of the Armed Forces eligible for the Transition Assistance Program to receive additional training in preparation for higher education or training, career or technical training, or entrepreneurship.

(Sec. 563) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2008 to revise the Yellow Ribbon Reintegration Program to:

  • expand eligibility for the program;
  • add quality of life services to the services that DOD may enter into partnerships to provide under the program;
  • provide flexibility in the number and timing of information, events, and activities under the program; and
  • require the Office for Reintegration Programs to assist in the collection and analysis of best practices regarding suicide prevention.

(Sec. 564) Adds one additional nomination for appointment to each military service academy by each Delegate in Congress from the territories of Guam, American Samoa, the U.S. Virgin Islands, and the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands.

(Sec. 565) Exempts two additional involuntary mobilization duty authorities from the five-year limit on reemployment rights: (1) orders of the Army, Navy, Marine Corps, and Air Force Reserve to active duty to respond to a major disaster or emergency; and (2) orders of the Selected Reserve to active duty for preplanned missions in support of the combatant commands.

(Sec. 566) Establishes a Job Training and Post-Service Placement Executive Committee within the Department of Veterans Affairs-Department of Defense Joint Executive Committee to: (1) review policies, procedures, and practices with respect to job training and post-service placement programs; and (2) identify changes to improve job training and post-service placement.

(Sec. 567) Authorizes DOD to carry out a pilot program to enhance efforts to provide job placement assistance and related employment services directly to members of the National Guard and Reserves.

(Sec. 568) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2012 to add six military occupational specialties to the pilot program to assess permitting enlisted members of the Armed Forces to obtain civilian credentialing or licensing for skills required for military occupational specialties or qualification for duty specialty codes.

(Sec. 569) Modifies the program to assist members serving in the Armed Forces in obtaining professional credentials to add specific requirements for providing training to members of the Armed Forces with mariner duties.

(Sec. 570) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report describing both civilian and military educational requirements necessary to meet any threats anticipated in the future security environment as described in the quadrennial defense review.

(Sec. 570a) Permits DOD and the Department of Homeland Security, with respect to the Coast Guard, to pay for a member of the active Air Force, Army, Navy, Coast Guard, the reserve components, defense contractors, or civilians with access to information systems and identified as critical to network defense to obtain professional and industry recognized credentials related to information technology and cyber security functions.

Subtitle G--Defense Dependents' Education and Military Family Readiness Matters

(Sec. 571) Authorizes appropriations for the continuation of assistance to local educational agencies impacted by the enrollment of dependent children of military members and DOD civilian employees.

(Sec. 572) Extends the authority for family support programs for immediate family members of members of the Armed Forces assigned to Special Operations Forces.

(Sec. 573) Authorizes DOD to provide grants to nonprofit organizations that provide services to improve the academic achievement of military dependent students.

(Sec. 574) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a study on the feasibility of using the Defense Enrollment Eligibility Reporting System to track dependents of members of the Armed Forces and DOD civilian employees who are elementary or secondary education students.

(Sec. 575) Expresses the sense of Congress that DOD should continue to support dependents of members of the Armed Forces in attending specialized camps for children grieving the loss of relatives or who have relatives suffering from post-traumatic stress or a behavioral health disorder.

Subtitle H--Decorations and Awards

(Sec. 581) Waives the statutory time limitation to authorize the Army to award the Distinguished-Service Cross to Edward G. Halcomb for service in the Korean War.

(Sec. 582) Prohibits Secretaries of military departments from revoking a service member's award unless the conduct of the service member during the time of the distinguished act was not honorable.

(Sec. 583) Awards the Purple Heart to six Active Duty service members who were killed during the 1995 bombing of the Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma.

(Sec. 584) Requires DOD to design and produce an Atomic Veterans Service Medal to honor retired and former members of the Armed Forces who are radiation-exposed veterans.

(Sec. 585) Deems Milton Holland who was awarded the Medal of Honor in recognition of his action in 1864 during the Battle of Chapin's Farm, Virginia, to have held the grade of captain in the regular Army.

(Sec. 586) Expresses the sense of Congress supporting the decision of the Army to posthumously promote Master Sergeant (retired) Naomi Horwitz to Sergeant Major.

Subtitle I--Reports and Other Matters

(Sec. 591) Permits the U.S. Air Force Institute of Technology to charge and retain tuition for instruction of persons other than Air Force personnel detailed for instruction at the Institute.

(Sec. 592) Recognizes the service of certain members of the Reserve Components by honoring them with status as veterans.

(Sec. 593) Expresses the sense of Congress to reaffirm support for the sacrifices made by military divers.

(Sec.594) Revises the priority order of recipients of adopted military animals and requires the Secretary of the military department concerned to make animals available for adoption under certain circumstances.

(Sec. 595) Requires DOD to develop a policy to coordinate the efforts of DOD and non-governmental suicide prevention organizations.

(Sec. 596) Expresses the sense of Congress that DOD and the Coast Guard should issue a Gold Star Installation Access Card to Gold Star family members who are the survivors of deceased members of the Armed Forces in order to expedite their ability to gain unescorted access to military installations to obtain services and benefits.

(Sec. 597) Requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to include specified details regarding the performance of regional offices in the annual report to Congress on quality assurance activities of the Veterans Benefits Administration.

(Sec. 598) Requires the Secretary concerned to: (1) provide preliminary mental health screenings before an individual enlists or is commissioned as an officer in an armed force, (2) use the screening as a baseline for subsequent mental health examinations, and (3) apply specified privacy laws to the screenings.

Prohibits the Secretary from using the screening to determine promotions and sets forth reporting requirements for mental and physical examinations.

(Sec. 599) Requires DOD to report to Congress on new Military Lending Act regulations related to the identification of covered borrowers, including: (1) the ability of the Defense Manpower Data Center to provide the information needed to determine whether a borrower is covered, or (2) an alternate mechanism for identifying covered borrowers.

Specifies requirements for Defense Manpower Data Center reports and meetings with private sector users.

TITLE VI--COMPENSATION AND OTHER PERSONNEL BENEFITS

Subtitle A--Pay and Allowances

(Sec. 601) Extends the authority of DOD to temporarily increase the rates of basic allowance for housing in areas impacted by natural disasters or experiencing a sudden influx of personnel.

(Sec. 602) Prohibits the Secretaries concerned from altering the amount of per diem allowance or the maximum reimbursement for a locality for members of the uniformed services and civilian employees based on the duration of a temporary duty assignment or civilian travel.

Subtitle B--Bonuses and Special and Incentive Pays

(Sec. 611) Extends certain bonus and special pay authorities for Reserve Forces.

(Sec. 612) Extends certain bonus and special pay authorities for health care professionals.

(Sec. 613) Extends certain bonus and special pay authorities for nuclear officers.

(Sec. 614) Extends the general bonus authority for enlisted members and officers, the special bonus and incentive pay authority for nuclear officers, special aviation incentive pay and bonus authorities, the special health professions incentive pay and bonus authorities, hazardous duty pay, assignment pay or special duty pay, skill incentive pay or the proficiency bonus, the contracting bonus for Senior Reserve Officers' Training Corps cadets and midshipmen, and the retention bonus for members with critical military skills or assigned to high-priority units.

(Sec. 615) Extends the authority for the aviation officer retention bonus, assignment incentive pay, the reenlistment bonus for active members, the enlistment bonus for active members, the incentive pay for members of precommissioning programs pursuing foreign language proficiency, the accession bonus for new officers in critical skills, the incentive bonus for conversion to military occupational specialty to ease personnel shortage, the incentive bonus for transfer between Armed Forces, and the accession bonus for officer candidates.

(Sec. 616) Authorizes the Navy to increase the maximum nuclear officer bonus if necessary to address declining nuclear officer retention and growing retention uncertainty.

(Sec. 617) Modifies the special aviation incentive pay and bonus authorities for officers. Permits the payment of aviation incentive pay to an officer who is not engaged in operational flying duty or proficiency flying duty, but serving in positions vital to the service. Permits the Secretaries of the military departments to continue providing aviation incentive pay to flight surgeons and other medical officers while assigned to operational flying duty. Increases the statutory limits for the aviation incentive pay and retention bonus.

(Sec. 618) Repeals the special travel and transportation allowance for survivors of deceased members of the Armed Forces from the Vietnam conflict to provide equal travel benefits regardless of the location of death or connection to a specific conflict.

Subtitle C--Modernization of Military Retirement System

(Sec. 631) Changes the current military retirement system by blending the current defined benefit retirement plan with a defined contribution plan allowing service members to contribute to a Thrift Savings Plan account with a government contribution matching program.

(Sec. 632) Changes the current uniformed services retirement system by blending the current defined benefit retirement plan with a defined contribution plan, lump sum career continuation pay, and retention bonuses paid at defined career milestones, while continuing a 20-year defined annuity.

(Sec. 633) Changes the current military retirement system by adding a mandatory lump sum career continuation pay at 12 years of service with an agreement by the service member to continue in service for 4 more years.

(Sec. 634) Establishes October 1, 2017, as the effective date for this subtitle, and requires the Secretaries concerned to submit an implementation plan to Congress.

Subtitle D--Commissary and Nonappropriated Fund Instrumentality Benefits and Operations

(Sec. 641) Requires DOD to ensure that there are no changes to the second destination transportation policy that currently applies to fresh fruit and vegetable supplies for commissaries in Asia and the Pacific until the Defense Commissary Agency submits a study to Congress.

(Sec. 642) Prohibits DOD from taking any actions to replace or consolidate the defense commissary and exchange systems prior to the submission of a required report on the defense commissary system.

Subtitle E--Other Matters

(Sec. 651) Requires DOD to increase the frequency of and make specified improvements to financial literacy and preparedness training for members of the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 652) Requires the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) to make available for purchase a memorial headstone or marker for members of a National Guard or Reserve component who performed training but did not serve on active duty.

TITLE VII--HEALTH CARE PROVISIONS

Subtitle A--TRICARE and Other Health Care Benefits

(Sec. 701) Requires DOD and the VA to establish a joint uniform formulary with respect to pharmaceutical agents that are critical for the transition of an individual from receiving treatment furnished by DOD to treatment furnished by the VA.

(Sec. 702) Requires DOD to ensure that every military medical treatment facility has a sufficient stock of Food and Drug Administration approved methods of contraception.

(Sec. 703) Requires DOD to provide a sufficient supply of prescription contraception to a female member of the Armed Forces prior to deployment.

(Sec. 704) Requires DOD to provide uninterrupted access to infertility treatment for members of the Armed Forces and their dependents.

(Sec. 705) Modifies residency requirements for certain beneficiaries to receive access to TRICARE Prime. Increases the authorization of appropriations for the Defense Health Program and specifies an offset.

Subtitle B--Health Care Administration

(Sec. 711) Requires DOD to establish a unified medical command to provide medical services to the Armed Forces and other DOD health care beneficiaries.

(Sec. 712) Establishes criteria under which licensed mental health counselors may be reimbursed under the TRICARE program.

(Sec. 713) Prohibits DOD from realigning or restructuring a military medical treatment facility until after a report is submitted to Congress.

(Sec. 714) Authorizes DOD to conduct a pilot program to evaluate whether operating a network of preferred retail pharmacies will generate cost savings.

Subtitle C--Reports and Other Matters

(Sec. 721) Extends the authority for the DOD-VA Health Care Sharing Incentive Fund for five years.

(Sec. 722) Extends the authority for the Joint Department of Defense-Department of Veterans Affairs Medical Facility Demonstration Fund through FY2017.

(Sec. 723) Limits the funds authorized by this bill that may be used for DOD Healthcare Management Systems Modernization until DOD makes a specified certification required by the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2014.

(Sec. 724) Requires the peer-reviewed Psychological Health and Traumatic Brain Injury Research Program to conduct a study on blast injury mechanics.

(Sec. 725) Expresses the sense of Congress regarding mental health counseling for members of the Armed Forces and their families.

(Sec. 726) Makes permanent the authority to provide transportation for certain dependents receiving obstetrical anesthesia services related to childbirth.

TITLE VIII--ACQUISITION POLICY, ACQUISITION MANAGEMENT, AND RELATED MATTERS

(Sec. 800) Expresses the sense of Congress that an improved defense acquisition system should be successful (timely delivery of affordable and effective military equipment and services), proactive, agile, transparent, and innovative.

Subtitle A--Acquisition Policy and Management

(Sec. 801) Requires the Chief of Staff of the Army, the Chief of Naval Operations, the Chief of Staff of the Air Force, and the Commandant of the Marine Corps to each submit to Congress a report on efforts to link and streamline the requirements, acquisition, and budget processes within the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Marine Corps.

(Sec. 802) Requires the Chief of Staff of the Army, the Chief of Naval Operations, the Chief of Staff of the Air Force, and the Commandant of the Marine Corps to review their current individual authorities related to defense acquisitions to develop recommendations to further or advance their roles in the development of requirements, acquisition processes, and the associated DOD budget practices.

(Sec. 803) Requires DOD to contract with an independent research entity that is a not-for-profit entity or a federally funded research and development center to study the factors leading to the filing of bid protests.

(Sec. 804) Requires DOD to establish and maintain a centralized capability to oversee the making of commercial item determinations for DOD procurements and to provide public access to the determinations. Sets forth procedures and requirements for procuring commercial items when a prior determination has been made for the same item.

(Sec. 805) Eliminates a requirement that the contracting officer, prior to making a determination that an item is a commercial item, determine in writing that the offeror of the item has submitted sufficient information to evaluate the reasonableness of the price through price analysis.

(Sec. 806) Permits the head of an agency to enter into multiyear contracts for the acquisition of property if there is a reasonable expectation that the use of a multiyear contract would result in lower total anticipated costs of carrying out the program than if the program were carried out through annual contracts. (Under current law, the head of an agency must determine that savings will be achieved prior to entering into the contract.)

(Sec. 807) Limits the expenditure of funds authorized for the operation of the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness until specified conditions are met regarding DOD's compliance with the requirement for an inventory of contracts for services.

Subtitle B--Workforce Development and Related Matters

(Sec. 811) Makes permanent the authority for the Defense Acquisition Workforce Development Fund and the associated expedited hiring authority.

(Sec. 812) Reinstitutes a dual-track career path for officers and enlisted personnel to gain experience and receive credit for both a primary career in combat arms and a functional secondary career in the acquisition field.

(Sec. 813) Includes acquisition matters addressed by military personnel in the definition of "joint matters" to enable military acquisition professionals to receive joint professional credit and end certain double experience requirements for officers who serve in acquisition positions.

(Sec. 814) Requires DOD to add an acquisition skills assessment to the biennial strategic workforce plan on critical skills and competencies of the civilian employee workforce.

(Sec. 815) Requires DOD to provide mandatory training for members of the Armed Forces and DOD employees responsible for conducting market research.

(Sec. 816) Requires DOD to contract with an independent research entity to study DOD strategic planning related to the defense acquisition workforce.

(Sec. 817) Extends the demonstration project relating to certain acquisition personnel management policies and procedures.

Subtitle C--Weapon Systems Acquisition and Related Matters

(Sec. 821) Expresses the sense of the Congress that DOD, Congress, and industry should develop an acquisition system characterized by highly disciplined program initiation coupled with agile program execution and balanced oversight.

(Sec. 822) Requires an acquisition strategy for each major defense acquisition program and each major system approved by a Milestone Decision Authority. Requires the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics to issue and maintain requirements for the content and the review and approval process for the strategies.

(Sec. 823) Requires the program acquisition strategy for each major defense acquisition program or major system to include an identification of major program risks and a risk management and mitigation strategy.

(Sec. 824) Modifies requirements for the determination of contract types for major defense acquisition programs and major systems.

(Sec. 825) Requires the Milestone Decision Authority to: (1) make a written determination, in lieu of a certification, before approving milestone A (initiates technology maturation and risk reduction) for major defense acquisition programs, and (2) provide an explanation of the basis for the determination to Congress upon request.

(Sec. 826) Requires the Milestone Decision Authority to: (1) make a written determination, in lieu of a certification, before approving milestone B (initiates engineering and manufacturing development) for major defense acquisition programs, and (2) provide an explanation of the basis for the determination to Congress upon request.

Subtitle D--Industrial Base Matters

(Sec. 831) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for FY1991 to codify and amend the Mentor-Protege Program, which provides incentives for major DOD contractors to furnish disadvantaged small business concerns with assistance to enhance capabilities to perform under DOD contracts.

(Sec. 832) Amends the Small Business Act to require the Small Business Administration (SBA) to annually provide to Congress certification of the accuracy and completeness of data reported on bundled and consolidated contracts. Requires GAO to report on the effectiveness of the certification process and assess whether contracts were accurately labeled as bundled or consolidated.

(Sec. 833) Requires: (1) the senior procurement executive or chief acquisition officer to announce through a public website that a determination has been made to bundle or consolidate contracts, and (2) the head of a contracting agency to announce through a public website that a determination has been made regarding a substantial bundling of contracts for a proposed procurement plan. Specifies requirements for the timing of the announcements.

(Sec. 834) Provides that Small Business Act requirements for certain contracts apply to contracts for goods, but not services or construction.

(Sec. 835) Requires DOD to contract with an independent entity to review: (1) regulations, practices, and sustainment requirements related to government access to and use of intellectual property rights of private sector firms; and (2) practices related to the procurement, management, and use of intellectual property rights to facilitate competition in sustainment of weapon systems throughout their life-cycle.

(Sec. 836) Requires certain auxiliary ship components to be procured from a manufacturer in the national technology and industrial base (the persons and organizations engaged in research, development, production, integration, services, or information technology activities conducted within the United States and Canada).

(Sec. 837) Requires DOD to ensure that every DOD tactical missile program that uses solid propellant as the primary propulsion system has at least one rocket motor supplier within the national technology and industrial base.

(Sec. 838) Adds the Administrator of the SBA to the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council.

(Sec. 839) Increases the amount of SBA surety bond guarantees from 70% to 90% percent. Requires the GAO to study the surety bond program and the impact of this amendment on the program. (A surety bond is a three-party instrument between a surety who agrees to be responsible for the debt or obligation of another, a contractor, and a project owner.)

(Sec. 840) Establishes certification requirements for Commercial Market Representatives and modifies the certification requirements for Procurement Center Representatives and Business Opportunity Specialists.

(Sec. 841) Includes consideration of success in attainment of small business subcontracting goals as a part of agency responsibilities for achieving small business goals.

(Sec. 842) Amends the Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2005 to revise requirements for small businesses located in base closure areas to participate in the Historically Underutilized Business Zone (HUBZone) program.

(Sec. 843) Requires agencies to consider the capabilities and past performances of the small businesses that submit offers as teams or joint ventures for a multiple award contract or when the contract is bundled or consolidated.

(Sec. 844) Requires the SBA to:

  • ensure the participation of a wide variety of industries and a broad spectrum of small businesses within each industry to meet small business contracting goals, and
  • develop a scorecard program for evaluating federal agency compliance with small business contracting goals.

Specifies requirements for the scorecard and requires GAO to review the methodology. Requires the SBA to report to Congress on specified details regarding contracts awarded to small businesses.

(Sec. 845) Establishes an Office of Hearings and Appeals in the SBA to: (1) impartially decide matters relating to certain program decisions of the Administrator, and (2) handle Freedom of Information Act requests and maintain records pursuant to the Privacy Act of 1974. Establishes procedures for the Office of Hearing and Appeals to consider petitions for the reconsideration of size standards for small business concerns.

(Sec. 846) Establishes limitations on the use of reverse auctions for awarding certain government contracts.

(Sec. 847) Expresses the sense of Congress that procurement authority for specialized fire hoses for the U.S. Forest Service should be reestablished as an activity of the General Services Administration.

Subtitle E--Other Matters

(Sec. 851) Requires the Director of Operational Test and Evaluation to consider the potential for increases in program cost estimates or delays in schedule estimates in the implementation of policies, procedures, and activities related to operational test and evaluation, and to take action to ensure that the activities do not unnecessarily impede schedules or increase costs.

(Sec. 852) Requires a contracting officer to consider evidence provided by an offeror of recent purchase prices paid by the government for the same or similar commercial items in establishing price reasonableness if the previous prices remain a valid reference for comparison after considering other relevant factors.

(Sec. 853) Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1994 to make permanent the transaction authority for the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency to carry out certain prototype projects that are directly relevant to enhancing the mission effectiveness of military personnel and the supporting platforms, systems, components, or materials proposed to be acquired or developed by DOD, or to improvement of platforms, systems, components, or materials in use by the Armed Forces.

Requires all parties to the transaction other than the federal government to be small businesses or nontraditional defense contractors, unless exceptional circumstances exist that require innovative business arrangements that are not feasible under another contract type.

(Sec. 854) Raises acquisition thresholds, including the simplified acquisition threshold, the micro-purchase threshold, the emergency procurement threshold, and the small business reservation threshold.

(Sec. 855) Changes the rounding method used for making inflation adjustments to certain acquisition-related dollar thresholds.

(Sec. 856) Repeals the requirement for separate manpower estimates for major defense acquisition programs.

(Sec. 857) Requires the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics to examine the decision authority related to acquisition of services and to develop and issue guidance to improve capabilities related to services contracts requirements development, source selection, and contract oversight and management.

(Sec. 858) States the responsibilities of the Secretary of Defense, the Defense Business Council, and other specified officials for the management of defense business systems.

(Sec. 859) Requires the Under Secretary of Defense for Acquisition, Technology, and Logistics to ensure that specified instructions and guidance are considered during preliminary design review of products that require strategic materials (critical to national security or specialty metals) over the life cycle of the product.

(Sec. 860) Requires DOD to use best value tradeoff source selection methods to the maximum extent practicable when procuring an item of personal protective equipment or critical safety items.

(Sec. 861) Expands the eligibility for contractors to include costs for rework and corrective action related to counterfeit electronic parts as allowable costs under DOD contracts.

(Sec. 862) Provides that the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Developmental Test and Evaluation and the Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Systems Engineering advise the Milestone Decision Authority regarding review and approval of developmental test plans and systems engineering plans, instead of reviewing and approving or disapproving the plans.

(Sec. 863) Extends the temporary limitation on the aggregate annual amounts available for DOD contract services.

(Sec. 864) Requires DOD to establish values and metrics for the services being procured and review the offeror's past performance prior to using a lowest price, technically acceptable (LPTA) evaluation method for the procurement of audit or audit readiness services.

(Sec. 865) Modifies the enhanced authority for DOD to acquire products and services produced in Afghanistan, Central Asian states, and Djibouti to create an exception from the requirements for products not produced in those countries, but included on the procurement list for products or services provided by a qualified nonprofit agency for the blind or other severely disabled individuals.

(Sec. 866) Requires the Federal Acquisition Regulatory Council to prescribe a regulation making clear that agency acquisition personnel are permitted and encouraged to engage in responsible and constructive exchanges with industry, if the exchanges are consistent with existing laws and regulations and do not promote an unfair competitive advantage to particular firms.

(Sec. 867) Requires the Office of Management and Budget to submit to Congress a plan for improving management of IT programs and projects.

(Sec. 868) Requires the President of the Defense Acquisition University to convene a review board annually with faculty representatives from relevant professional schools and degree-granting institutions of DOD and military departments to review and synchronize defense acquisition curricula across DOD.

(Sec. 869) Specifies that the Defense Acquisition University should provide for research and analysis of defense acquisition policy issues from academic institutions that offer in-depth analysis of the entire defense acquisition decision support system from both a business and public policy perspective and from an operational and information sciences perspective.

(Sec. 870) Requires DOD to conduct and brief Congress on an assessment of the application of the Open Trusted Technology Provider Standard to DOD procurements for information technology and cyber security acquisitions.

(Sec. 871) Modifies the justification and approval process for certain sole-source contracts for small business concerns.

TITLE IX--DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE ORGANIZATION AND MANAGEMENT

(Sec. 901) Redesignates the Department of the Navy as the Department of the Navy and Marine Corps, and changes the title of its Secretary to the Secretary of the Navy and Marine Corps.

(Sec. 902) Changes the requirement for the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to review the Unified Command Plan including the missions, responsibilities, and force structure of each combatant command, from not less than every two years to not less than every four years.

(Sec. 903) Revises the functions of the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to include additional joint force integration functions currently overseen by the Chairman, as a result of the disestablishment of U.S. Joint Forces Command and the deletion of that command from the Unified Command Plan.

(Sec. 904) Expresses the sense of the Congress regarding the U.S. Marine Corps.

(Sec. 905) Amends the existing requirement for DOD to develop a plan for streamlining DOD management headquarters to require an accurate baseline accounting of defense headquarters budgets and personnel, and more specific information on actual and planned reductions in management headquarters. Requires DOD to implement its planned reduction in management headquarters budgets and personnel for certain organizations in the National Capital Region. Provides that civilian employees funded from working capital funds are not subject to the reduction requirement.

(Sec. 906) Expresses the sense of Congress that DOD should proceed with the collaborative work with employee representatives on the "New Beginnings" performance management and workforce incentive system and begin implementing the new system at the earliest possible date.

(Sec. 907) Establishes guidelines for the conversion of functions performed by civilian or contractor personnel to performance by military personnel.

TITLE X--GENERAL PROVISIONS

Subtitle A--Financial Matters

(Sec. 1001) Permits DOD to make transfers between amounts authorized for FY2016 in division A of this bill, subject to specified limitations and a congressional notification requirement.

(Sec. 1002) Permits DOD to transfer up to $150 million to the nuclear weapons and naval reactor programs of the National Nuclear Security Administration (NNSA) if the amount authorized to be appropriated or otherwise made available for FY2016 for the weapons activities of the NNSA is less than $8.9 billion.

(Sec. 1003) Requires DOD to work with the Federal Accounting Standards Advisory Board to establish accounting standards to value large and unordinary general property, plant, and equipment items.

(Sec. 1004) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report ranking all military departments and defense agencies in order of how advanced they are in achieving auditable financial statements as required by law.

Subtitle B--Counter-Drug Activities

(Sec. 1011) Extends the authority to provide support for counterdrug activities of certain foreign governments.

(Sec. 1012) States the policy of the United States to prioritize a Plan Central America to address the threatening levels of violence, instability, illicit trafficking, and transnational organized crime that challenge the sovereignty of Central American nations and security of the United States.

Subtitle C--Naval Vessels and Shipyards

(Sec. 1021) Restricts the overhaul or repair of U.S. vessels in foreign shipyards. Excludes emergency or voyage repairs required during an overseas homeporting period.

(Sec. 1022) Extends the authority of DOD to use Navy operation and maintenance accounts to fund the cost of meals on U.S. naval and naval auxiliary vessels for non-military personnel.

(Sec. 1023) Limits the use of FY2016 funds for the retirement, inactivation, or storage of Ticonderoga class cruisers and Whidbey Island-class amphibious ships. Requires the modernization of two Ticonderoga-class cruisers to begin in FY2016 after sufficient materials are available to begin the modernization period. Limits the modernization period to two years, and permits the Navy to extend the period for another six months.

(Sec. 1024) Prohibits the removal of ballistic missile capabilities from any of the Ticonderoga class cruisers until the Navy certifies to Congress that it has obtained the ballistic missile capabilities required by the most recent Navy Force Structure Assessment or determined to upgrade the cruisers with an equal or improved capability.

Subtitle D--Counterterrorism

(Sec. 1031) Makes permanent the authority to make rewards for providing information or non-lethal assistance to U.S. government personnel or allied forces participating in a combined operation conducted outside the United States against terrorism, or providing information or assistance beneficial to force protection associated with the operation.

(Sec. 1032) Removes an exemption of operations executed within the Islamic Republic of Afghanistan pursuant to the Authorization for Use of Military Force from congressional notification requirements for sensitive military operations.

(Sec. 1033) Modifies reporting requirements for funds related to programs for combating terrorism.

(Sec. 1034) Amends a provision of Supplemental Appropriations Act, 2009 requiring the President to report to Congress on individuals detained at U.S. Naval Station, Guantanamo Bay, Cuba (Guantanamo), including a summary of all contact between individuals formerly detained at Guantanamo and individuals associated with a foreign terrorist group, and whether any of the contacts included information or discussion about hostilities against the United States or its allies. Requires the summary of contacts between individuals to contain any means of communication and all contact, regardless of content.

(Sec. 1035) Requires the President to include in reports to Congress details regarding recidivism of individuals formerly detained at Guantanamo.

(Sec. 1036) Prohibits the use of funds to transfer or release detainees at Guantanamo to or within the United States, its territories, or possessions.

(Sec. 1037) Prohibits DOD from using funds to modify or construct any facility in the United States, its territories, or possessions to house any detainee transferred from Guantanamo for the purposes of detention or imprisonment in the custody or under control of DOD.

(Sec. 1038) Prohibits DOD from using funds to transfer, release, or assist in the transfer or release of any individual detained at Guantanamo to a combat zone.

(Sec. 1039) Prohibits DOD from using funds to transfer or release any individual detained at Guantanamo to the individual's country of origin or any other foreign country or entity, unless DOD provides a certification to Congress addressing specified requirements.

Prohibits DOD from using funds to transfer an individual to a country if there is a confirmed case of any individual transferred from Guantanamo to the same country or entity engaging in terrorist activity after the transfer.

Permits DOD to waive certification requirements for national security, subject to reporting requirements and exceptions.

(Sec. 1040) Requires the Department of Justice and DOD to submit to Congress specified correspondence related to the transfer of individuals detained at Guantanamo to Qatar.

(Sec. 1041) Requires DOD to submit to the House Committee on Armed Services unredacted copies of all documents produced in response to the committee's June 9, 2014, request for information regarding the transfer of five individuals from Guantanamo to Qatar. Limits the obligation of FY2016 funds by Office of the Secretary of Defense until DOD submits unredacted copies of certain documents to the committee.

(Sec. 1042) Prohibits DOD from using funds for the transfer or release of any individual detained at Guantanamo to Yemen or any entity within Yemen.

Subtitle E--Miscellaneous Authorities and Limitations

(Sec. 1051) Expands the transfer authority provided to the National Sea-Based Deterrence Fund from the Department of the Navy to DOD. Provides the Navy with authority to:

  • enter into economic order quantity contracts for ballistic missile submarines and other nuclear powered vessels,
  • use the Fund to enter into contracts for advance construction of national sea-based deterrence vessels,
  • use incremental funding to enter into contracts for certain items, and
  • use the Fund to provide incentives for investments in critical infrastructure at nuclear capable shipyards and critical sub-tier vendors.

(Sec. 1052) Requires DOD to create a website providing information on property transferred under the DOD excess property program. Establishes eligibility requirements that must be met prior to transferring certain types of property to recipients. Requires a federally funded research and development center, the GAO, and DOD to review program objectives, efficacy, and training requirements.

(Sec. 1053) Limits the transfer of certain AH-64 Apache helicopters from the Army National Guard to the regular Army or the reduction of related personnel levels before June 30, 2016.

(Sec. 1054) Requires DOD to amend the Air Transportation Eligibility Regulation to authorize space-available travel for environmental morale leave by unaccompanied spouses and dependent children of service members deployed for at least 30 consecutive days under priority category IV.

(Sec. 1055) Permits DOD to establish a pilot program to assess information-related and strategic communications capabilities to support the tactical, operational, and strategic requirements of the various combatant commanders, including urgent and emergent operational needs, and the operational and theater security cooperation plans of the Geographic and Functional Combatant Commanders.

(Sec. 1056) Prohibits the Navy from using FY2016 funds to retire, prepare to retire, transfer, or place in storage any Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron 84 (HSC-84) or Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron 85 (HSC-85) aircraft or to change the manning levels of the squadrons. Permits a waiver if the Secretary of the Navy certifies that he has conducted a cost-benefit analysis identifying savings to DOD and has identified a replacement capability to meet all operational requirements.

(Sec. 1057) Prohibits the use of funds for the destruction of anti-personnel landmines of the United States until specified conditions are met. Includes an exception for any anti-personnel land mine that has become unsafe or poses a safety risk if not demilitarized or destroyed.

(Sec. 1058) Prohibits the use of funds to modify command and control relationships to give Fleet Forces Command operational and administrative control of Navy forces assigned to the Pacific Fleet.

(Sec. 1059) Prohibits the closure of Guantanamo and requires the President to ensure that the obligations of the United States under Article III of the Treaty between the United States and Cuba signed on May 29, 1934, are met.

(Sec. 1060) Prohibits the use of funds to: (1) close or abandon Guantanamo, (2) relinquish control of Guantanamo to Cuba, or (3) modify the 1934 treaty Between the United States and Cuba, including a modification of the boundaries of Guantanamo, unless it is ratified by the Senate.

(Sec. 1060a) Permits DOD to participate in a Civilian Aviation Asset Military Partnership Pilot Program to provide grants to eligible airports to: (1) improve aviation infrastructure; or (2) to repair, replace, or otherwise improve an eligible tower facility.

(Sec. 1060b) Permits DOD to sell or donate excess personal property to federal or state agencies for border security activities.

(Sec. 1060c) Prohibits the use of funds to deactivate the 440th airlift wing until DOD certifies that the deactivation will not affect the military readiness for the airborne and special operations units stationed at Fort Bragg, North Carolina.

Subtitle F--Studies and Reports

(Sec. 1061) Requires DOD to include in the annual budget submission a report to Congress containing summaries of the defense planning guidance and contingency planning guidance. Limits the expenditure of Operation and Maintenance--Defense-Wide funds for the Office of the Secretary until after the report is submitted.

(Sec. 1062) Amends the National Nuclear Security Administration Act to provide GAO with additional time to complete a required report on the NNSA budget request.

Amends the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2010 to eliminate a requirement for GAO to conduct a final review of all projects carried out by the Department of Energy's Office of Environmental Management using American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 funds.

(Sec. 1063) Requires DOD to report to Congress on plans for implementing the geographically distributed force laydown in the area of responsibility of U.S. Pacific Command.

(Sec. 1064) Requires DOD to contract with an independent research entity to carry out a study of the DOD national security strategy formulation process.

(Sec. 1065) Requires the Office of Net Assessment to conduct a study on DOD's role in the formulation of long-term strategy.

(Sec. 1066) Requires DOD to report to Congress on the potential threat posed to members of the Armed Forces of the U.S. Naval Forces Central Command and the U.S. Fifth Fleet from Naval Support Activity Bahrain, and their families, should there be an increase in violence in Bahrain.

(Sec. 1067) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report addressing the suitability of existing capabilities to detect, identify, and disable remotely piloted aircraft operating within special use and restricted airspace.

(Sec. 1068) Requires the Air Force to submit to Congress a report addressing the immediate and critical training and operational needs of the remotely piloted aircraft community.

(Sec. 1069) Exempts meetings of the National Commission on the Future of the Army from specified requirements of the Federal Advisory Committee Act, unless the meetings are attended by five or more members of the Commission.

Subtitle G--Repeal or Revision of National Defense Reporting Requirements

(Sec. 1071) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to military personnel issues.

(Sec. 1072) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to readiness.

(Sec. 1073) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to Naval vessels and the Merchant Marine.

(Sec. 1074) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to nuclear weapons, proliferation, and related matters.

(Sec. 1075) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to missile defense.

(Sec. 1076) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to acquisition.

(Sec. 1077) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to civilian personnel.

(Sec. 1078) Repeals or revises specified reporting requirements related to combating terrorism, technological maturity and integration risk of critical technologies, system engineering, the Regional Defense Counterterrorism Fellowship Program, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA), airlift requirements, in-kind payments, and the Navy Next Generation Enterprise Networks Program.

Subtitle H--Other Matters

(Sec. 1081) Makes technical and clerical amendments to existing laws.

(Sec. 1082) Requires DOD to establish an executive agent for and report to Congress on the oversight and management of alternative compensatory control measures.

(Sec. 1083) Eliminates a requirement for the Navy to make funds available annually to support the Ocean Research Advisory Panel.

(Sec. 1084) Requires DOD to include with the annual budget submission specified details regarding the level of readiness of Civil Reserve Air Fleet carriers.

(Sec. 1085) Authorizes the Army to transfer surplus firearms, spare parts, and related accessories to the Corporation for the Promotion of Rifle Practice and Firearms Safety, also known as the Civilian Marksmanship Program.

(Sec. 1086) Modifies specified administrative requirements for transferring aircraft from the Reserve Components to the Active Components of the Air Force.

(Sec. 1087) Reestablishes the Commission to Assess the Threat to the United States from Electromagnetic Pulse Attack and sets forth requirements for membership, the purpose, and duties.

(Sec. 1088) Requires DOD to develop a strategy to counter unconventional warfare threats posed by adversarial state and non-state actors.

(Sec. 1089) Requires the Navy to submit a mine countermeasures master plan to Congress with the annual budget submission for each fiscal year from FY2018-FY2023.

(Sec. 1090) Requires DOD and the Department of State to notify and brief Congress after an evacuation operation of a U.S. embassy or consulate involving the use of the Armed Forces.

(Sec. 1091) Requires DOD to determine and disclose the transportation costs incurred for certain congressional trips outside the United States.

(Sec. 1092) Requires the President to designate an existing federal officer as the Interagency Hostage Recovery Coordinator to coordinate efforts to secure the release of U.S. persons who are hostages of hostile groups or state sponsors of terrorism. Specifies duties, reporting requirements, and limitations on authority for the position.

(Sec. 1093) Specifies procedures, requirements, and limitations that apply when members of the Armed Forces provide support to civilian law enforcement agencies during situations involving bombings of places of public use, government facilities, public transportation systems, and infrastructure facilities.

(Sec. 1094) Expresses the sense of Congress that a technical correction to the Carl Levin and Howard P. "Buck" McKeon National Defense Authorization Act of Fiscal Year 2015 should be enacted in order to expeditiously carry out the intent of provisions authorizing the refinancing of the loan funding the Pacific Coast groundfish fishing capacity reduction program.

(Sec. 1095) Requires the President to issue an annual proclamation calling on the people of the United States to observe two minutes of silence on Veterans Day.

(Sec. 1096) Requires the Air Force to conduct a business case analysis of the decision to maintain 10 C-130J aircraft at Keesler Air Force Base, Mississippi.

(Sec. 1097) Expresses the sense of Congress that the National Guard should seek ways to improve and expand its communications and networking capabilities to provide for enhanced performance and resilience in the face of cyber-attacks or disruptions, as well as other instances of degradation.

(Sec. 1098) Expresses the sense of Congress that taxpayers should not pay any organization to honor the service of members of the Armed Forces and that funds that would have been used for this purpose should be directed to post-traumatic stress disorder research and treatment.

TITLE XI--CIVILIAN PERSONNEL MATTERS

(Sec. 1101) Amends the Emergency Supplemental Appropriations Act for Defense, the Global War on Terror, and Hurricane Recovery, 2006 to extend the authority for federal agencies to grant allowances, benefits, and gratuities comparable to those provided to members of the foreign service to an agency's civilian employees on official duty in a combat zone.

(Sec. 1102) Authorizes DOD to provide additional allowances and benefits to employees of the Defense Clandestine Service.

(Sec. 1103) Extends the authority for overtime pay for Navy employees assigned to temporary duty to perform work aboard or dockside in direct support of the nuclear aircraft carrier that is forward deployed in Japan.

(Sec. 1104) Permits the noncompetitive conversion of students that have graduated from an applicable institution of higher education to a permanent appointment. Increases the limit on the number of appointments allowable in a calendar year.

(Sec. 1105) Provides hiring preferences for federal employment to members of a Reserve Component of the Armed Forces who have successfully completed Officer Candidate Training or entry level skill training and are performing a 6-year commitment, have completed 10 years of service, or are retired.

TITLE XII--MATTERS RELATING TO FOREIGN NATIONS

Subtitle A--Assistance and Training

(Sec. 1201) Extends the authority for DOD to provide supplies, services, transportation, and other logistical support to coalition forces supporting U.S. operations in Iraq and Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1202) Requires DOD, in coordination with the Department of State, to develop a strategic framework for DOD security cooperation to guide prioritization of resources and activities.

(Sec. 1203) Extends and modifies the authorization for the National Guard State Partnership Program (SPP) to:

  • specify that SPP should support the national interests and security cooperation goals and objectives of the United States;
  • require the National Guard to establish, maintain, update, and submit to DOD a list of core competencies, consistent with the roles and missions of the Armed Forces to support SPP activities; and
  • require DOD to establish a fund to administer and execute the funds provided for SPP and to include the fund in budget requests.

(Sec. 1204) Extends the authorization for non-reciprocal exchanges of defense personnel between the United States and foreign countries.

(Sec. 1205) Permits specified funds to be used to monitor and evaluate DOD overseas humanitarian, disaster, and civic aid programs. Requires DOD to brief Congress on mechanisms to evaluate the programs.

Subtitle B--Matters Relating to Afghanistan and Pakistan

(Sec. 1211) Extends the Commanders' Emergency Response Program in Afghanistan and authorizes FY2016 appropriations.

(Sec. 1212) Extends the authority for reimbursement of coalition nations for support provided to the United States for military operations in Afghanistan.

Extends the requirement for DOD to: (1) notify Congress prior to making any reimbursement to Pakistan, of any logistical, military, or other support that Pakistan provides to the United States; and (2) certify, prior to providing reimbursement, that Pakistan has met specified requirements.

Provides that $400 million of the total amount of reimbursements and support authorized for Pakistan during FY2016 shall not be eligible for a national security waiver unless DOD certifies that Pakistan has met specified requirements.

(Sec. 1213) Expresses the sense of Congress on U.S. policy and strategy in Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1214) Extends the authority to acquire products and services produced in countries along a major supply route of Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1215) Extends the authority to transfer defense articles and provide defense services to the military and security forces of Afghanistan. Extends the quarterly reporting requirement for this authority. Provides that excess defense articles transferred from DOD stocks to the military and security forces of Afghanistan will not be subject to specified authorities and limitations in the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961.

(Sec. 1216) Expresses the sense of Congress that it is in the interest of the United States to continue to assist Afghan partners who have served as translators or interpreters and those who have performed sensitive and trusted activities for U.S. forces.

Amends the Afghan Allies Protection Act of 2009 to provide special immigrant status for Afghans employed in Afghanistan by the Resolute Support Mission (a NATO-led mission to provide further training, advice and assistance for the Afghan security forces and institutions) or any successor organization.

(Sec. 1217) Requires the Secretary of Defense and the Secretary of State to report to Congress on efforts of the Secretaries to engage U.S. manufacturers in procurement opportunities related to equipping the Afghan National Security Forces.

(Sec. 1218) Requires the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction to report to Congress on the extent to which the Office of the Special Inspector General for Afghanistan Reconstruction has adequate access to financial records of the government of Afghanistan to audit the use of funds authorized for assistance for Afghanistan.

(Sec. 1219) Expresses the sense of Congress that Dr. Shakil Afridi is an international hero and that Pakistan should release him immediately from prison.

Subtitle C--Matters Relating to Syria and Iraq

(Sec. 1221) Extends the authority for the Office of Security Cooperation in Iraq to conduct training activities in support of the Iraqi Ministry of Defense and Counter Terrorism Service personnel. Limits FY2016 funding authorized for this purpose and sets forth reporting requirements.

(Sec. 1222) Requires DOD and the Department of State to submit to Congress a comprehensive strategy for the Middle East and to counter Islamic extremism.

(Sec. 1223) Authorizes appropriations for assistance to the military and security forces of Iraq and requires specified funds to be used for direct assistance to the Kurdish Peshmerga, the Sunni tribal security forces with a national security mission, and the Iraqi Sunni National Guard.

Requires DOD and the Department of State to: (1) submit to Congress an assessment of the extent to which Iraq is meeting certain conditions relating to political inclusion of ethnic and sectarian minorities within the security forces of Iraq, and (2) withhold FY2016 assistance to Iraq if the conditions are not met.

Requires that the Kurdish Peshmerga, the Sunni tribal security forces with a national security mission, and the Iraqi Sunni National Guard be deemed a country, and receive specified assistance under this section, if Iraq has not met the conditions or an assessment is not submitted.

(Sec. 1224) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report on U.S. Armed Forces deployed in support of Operation Inherent Resolve (operations in Iraq and Syria against the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant or ISIL).

(Sec. 1225) Modifies the authority to provide assistance to the vetted Syrian opposition to permit DOD to submit a reprogramming or transfer request to use funds made available for the Syria Train and Equip Fund for this purpose. Sets forth reporting requirements, including the submission of a comprehensive strategy regarding Iraq and Syria, and updates and certifications regarding the strategy.

(Sec. 1226) Authorizes DOD to provide assistance on a reimbursement basis to the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan to support and enhance the efforts of its Armed Forces to sustain security along its border with the Syrian Arab Republic and the Republic of Iraq. Authorizes appropriations and sets forth reporting requirements for this authority.

(Sec. 1227) Requires DOD to report to Congress on the efforts of Turkey to fight terrorism, including efforts to combat the flow of foreign fighters through its country into Syria, and its relationship with Hamas.

(Sec. 1228) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a report that assesses the potential effectiveness, risks, and operational requirements of the establishment of: (1) a no-fly zone over part or all of Syria, and (2) one or more safe zones in Syria for internally displaced people or for the facilitation of humanitarian assistance.

Subtitle D--Matters Relating to Iran

(Sec. 1231) Extends the requirement for an annual report on the military power of Iran and adds a requirement to include an assessment of transfers of military equipment, technology, and training to Iran from non-Iranian sources.

(Sec. 1232) Expresses the sense of the Congress on Iran's nuclear program and military activities.

(Sec. 1233) Requires DOD to report to Congress on the military posture required in the Middle East to deter Iran from developing a nuclear weapon.

(Sec. 1234) Prohibits DOD from authorizing certain military-to-military exchanges and contact with Iran until DOD certifies that Iran: (1) has ended its ballistic missile program, (2) is no longer listed by the Secretary of State as a state sponsor of terrorism; and (3) has recognized Israel as a Jewish state. Includes an exception for search-and-rescue or humanitarian operations or exercises.

(Sec. 1235) Requires DOD to provide Congress with a copy of any security agreement or commitment associated with Iran's nuclear weapons program that has been provided by the United States to any country in the Middle East. Prohibits the use of FY2016 funds for the security agreement or commitment until DOD certifies that the agreement has been provided to Congress.

Requires the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to provide DOD with an analysis of the U.S. military force structure and posture, as well as the associated costs, required to meet any security agreement or commitment in the Middle East.

(Sec. 1236) Provides that nothing in this bill authorizes the use of force against Iran.

Subtitle E--Matters Relating to the Russian Federation

(Sec. 1241) Requires DOD to provide specified updates and notifications to Congress regarding: (1) the testing, production, deployment, and sale or transfer to other states or non-state actors of the Club-K cruise missile system by the Russian Federation, and (2) the coordination of allied responses to the activities related to the Club-K cruise missile system. Requires the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to develop a strategy to detect, defend against, and defeat the Club-K cruise missile system.

(Sec. 1242) Requires DOD to submit quarterly notifications to Congress regarding the status of potential deployment of nuclear weapons by the Russian Federation onto the territory of the Ukrainian Republic. Requires the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff to develop a strategy to respond to the military threat posed by the Russian Federation deploying covered weapons systems onto the territory of the Ukrainian Republic.

(Sec. 1243) Requires the President to notify Congress regarding Russia's continued violation of or compliance with the Treaty on Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces (INF). Requires DOD to submit reports to Congress on the status of discussions with allies regarding Russia's violation of the INF Treaty. Requires the President, if Russia has not begun to return to full compliance with the INF treaty, to begin developing counterforce and countervailing capabilities and report to Congress on development and deployment.

(Sec. 1244) Extends from 30 to 90 days the time period by which the President must notify Congress after the Russian Federation submits a proposal to modify or introduce a new aircraft or sensor under the Open Skies Treaty. Requires the views of any relevant combatant commander to be provided in the assessment of the national security implications of any new aircraft or sensor proposed to be deployed by the Russian Federation under the Treaty.

(Sec. 1245) Expresses the sense of the Congress on support for Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania, including support for their sovereignty, concern over military actions of the Russian Federation against these nations, and encouragement for further defense cooperation between the United States and these nations.

(Sec. 1246) Expresses the sense of Congress on support for Georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity as well as support for continued cooperation between the United States and Georgia.

(Sec. 1247) Prohibits funds from being used to: (1) implement any action or policy that recognizes the sovereignty of the Russian Federation over Crimea, its airspace, or its territorial waters; or (2) provide assistance to a country that has taken affirmative steps to recognize or support the Russian Federation's occupation of Crimea. Permits DOD to waive the prohibition by certifying to Congress that is in the national interest.

(Sec. 1248) Prohibits funds from being used for any bilateral military-to-military contact or cooperation between the United States and Russia until DOD certifies to Congress that Russia:

  • is no longer illegally occupying Ukrainian territory;
  • is respecting the sovereignty of all Ukrainian territory;
  • is no longer taking actions that are inconsistent with the INF Treaty; and
  • has not sold or otherwise transferred the Club-K land attack cruise missile system to any foreign country or person during FY2015.

Permits waivers and exceptions under specified circumstances.

(Sec. 1249) Prohibits the use of funds for implementing the New START Treaty until the President submits a specified certification to Congress regarding Russian activities in Ukrainian territory and compliance with specified treaties.

Subtitle F--Matters Relating to the Asia-Pacific Region

(Sec. 1251) Expresses the sense of Congress recognizing the 70th anniversary of the end of the Allied military engagement in the Pacific theater, and the end of the Second World War.

(Sec. 1252) Expresses the sense of Congress regarding the consolidation of U.S. military facilities in Okinawa, Japan and that the Henoko location remains the only option for the Futenma Replacement Facility.

(Sec. 1253) Requires the President to: (1) develop an overall strategy to promote U.S. interests in the Indo-Asia-Pacific region, (2) issue a Presidential Policy Directive to relevant departments and agencies that implements the strategy, and (3) include in the budget submission a description of how the programs and projects funded in the request align with the strategy.

(Sec. 1254) Expresses the sense of Congress on the U.S. alliance with Japan, including that the United States highly values the alliance, supports recent changes in Japanese defense policy, and reaffirms its commitment to the alliance.

(Sec. 1255) Expresses the sense of Congress regarding opportunities to enhance the U.S. alliance with the Republic of Korea.

(Sec. 1256) Requires DOD to submit to Congress a copy of the policy regarding foreign disclosure or technology release of Aegis Ashore capability to allies, including Japan, that possess sea-based Aegis weapons system-equipped naval vessels.

(Sec. 1257) Requires DOD to invite Taiwan to participate in the maritime exercise known as the Rim of the Pacific Exercise if China has been invited to participate in the exercise.

Subtitle G--Other Matters

(Sec. 1261) Extends the authority of DOD to develop, manage, and execute a Non-Conventional Assisted Recovery personnel recovery program for isolated DOD, U.S. government, and other designated personnel supporting U.S. national interests worldwide. Authorizes the use of specified O&M appropriations for the program.

(Sec. 1262) Amends the Arms Control and Disarmament Act to revise the requirements for the annual report on arms control compliance (also known as the Report on Adherence to and Compliance with Arms Control, Nonproliferation, and Disarmament Agreements and Commitments). Requires the Director of National Intelligence to provide, in any year in which the report is not submitted by the deadline, a report detailing inconsistent behavior by a state party to an arms control treaty or related agreement to which the United States is a party.

(Sec. 1263) Makes permanent the authority for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) Special Operations Headquarters.
